posts.body:
>>2d140da4-342e-44e0-b555-de33b88dbacd

Still can't get the tor hidden service to work running Artix on a fresh install. Following this guide. 

I had it working on my last system, but I wanted to get rid of systemd.

Tor doesn't seem to be creating an auth cookie at all, nor can I get the daemon to load on boot.

I get permission errors if I try to start the hidden service manually. If I'm doing this right, I'm new to OpenRC. I double-checked, and my user is in the tor group.

~]$ /etc/init.d/tor start
bash: /etc/init.d/tor: Permission denied

and

rc-service tor start
 * rc-service: Permission denied


Zeronet throws this error:

TorManager Disabling Tor, because error while accessing Tor proxy at port 127.0.0.1:9050: No connection


Whereas tor throws me a bunch of random permission errors, depending on what I'm trying to do.

I also can't access zeronet from the actual tor browser itself either, but its working in other browsers. Yeah, I remembered to whitelist the zeronet port inside the tor browser.

Any ideas? I've been digging through forum posts and scratching my head trying random things for a whole day now... This guide works great on my arch and debian boxes, maybe its something to do with me being a retard who doesn't know how to use OpenRC yet?

>>cd563e74-dc72-49df-b715-7f7be1e0f96b
Honestly I've tried so many things, that I can't remember if I tried a manual install or not. I'll try again. I know that I tried the version in the arch repos, and both versions in the aur.

Thanks, I didn't think to check Zerotalk!

>>c098df4c-b258-4372-b8a1-50c6b890c676
The logs only show me that zeronet can't access any tor controller. 

>>7be604e9-a8fa-4754-baa5-fe9bc9e03d4e
Yep I added it to the proxy whitelist in the tor browser. Firefox doesn't need it to function.

>try this:
>sudo /etc/init.d/tor start
>sudo rc-service tor start
>sudo systemctl start tor
>sudo systemctl start debian-tor

Already tried all those commands except the systemd ones, because I'm not running systemd. The first two throw permissions errors.

And yeah I did all the /etc/tor/torrc edits (uncomments, and added arguments)

Just installed it manually straight from the tor website, since my last post.. same thing.. Tried AUR's copy of tor again as well.

Zeronet itself is working fine.. The problem is I can't get the tor hidden service to run, nor can zeronet seem to communicate with tor while running the browser manually.

>>5a3b2b35-e7a9-4e16-9064-a1618349c87e

The only thread on zerotalk about my error

"TorManager Tor controller connect error: IOError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/var/lib/tor/control_auth_cookie' in TorManager.py line 200"

TorManager Disabling Tor, because error while accessing Tor proxy at port 127.0.0.1:9050: No connection


had no solution :( just monkies saying that they rebooted one day and it magically worked.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1546815090_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS
^ thread


For whatever reason though, on this latest re-install of tor, it no longer throws the cookie auth failure, only this:

TorManager Disabling Tor, because error while accessing Tor proxy at port 127.0.0.1:9050: No connection

I already spent the last day going through every single thread that comes up on duck, about the tor hidden service not running, or the tor hidden service throwing permission errors. No solutions so far :(

>>96ccefdf-8d1e-4e2c-90e4-77da54b187f3
Sorry, it is set to directory /var/lib/tor;

I was lazy and copy/pasted from one of the posts on the zerotalk thread.. WHOOPS

When I installed the Tor package, the /var/lib/tor directory did not have read permissions.

I already chmod'ed group to read permissions (chmod 750) but it made no difference..

sudo rc-service tor start
 * rc-service: Permission denied

/etc/init.d/tor has read+write for owner, read access for group, and read access for other.

>>cd57f6de-7712-469e-9314-9524c384fba3
PROBLEM SOLVED

If anyone has a similar issue to me, with tor hidden service permissions, all you need to do is run

sudo chmod +x /etc/init.d/tor

I have no idea why I never checked to see if it had execute permissions. I feel like a retard now :D

>>327574cc-74f6-4e27-a292-11da3a0de14f

I'm currently using the version of Tor on AUR. I tried the pacman one too.

OK, so its half-solved. I can execute the tor service from a terminal with "sudo rc-service tor start" but it does not initialize on boot. 

I've only been using OpenRC for like, two days.. Is there anything I need to do for it to load the service on boot, other than have an init script in init.d? 

Either way.. At least I can post from tor now. 

EDIT FOR OPENRC USERS:
"rc-update add tor"

pacman/yaourt don't automatically add the daemon to openrc's init like it would with systemd. easy fix.
